clinical_study.brief_title: Replacing Protein Via Enteral Nutrition in a Stepwise Approach in Critically Ill Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Replacing Protein Via Enteral Nutrition in a Stepwise Approach in Critically Ill Patients: Feasibility Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: King Abdullah International Medical Research Center

clinical_study.source: King Abdullah International Medical Research Center

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, we will explore the feasibility of doing a randomized controlled trial in our Intensive care department, King Abdulaziz Medical City, Riyadh which will test a two-step approach to protein intake in which moderate amount is given in the first 5 days followed by a step-up to higher protein (with supplementation of whey protein) compared to continuation on moderate protein.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study will use a modified version of the enteral feeding protocol which was developed by KAMC ICU team and has been studied and published 20. For reference the protocol used at adult ICU at KAMC is displayed in the attached appendix and the summary of the latest SCCM guidelines is outlined below for reference purposes. After confirmation of the tube tip placement in the stomach or in post-pyloric location by plain x-ray, feeding will be started at 30 cc/hour and advanced by 10 cc/h every four hours. For tubes of gastric placement, residuals are checked every 4 hours. Residuals are not checked for post-pyloric tubes unless there are signs of feeding intolerance such as vomiting, abdominal distention or ileus. In such cases, an attempt to aspirate is made through the feeding tube. If unable to aspirate because of the small size, a second larger size tube could- at the discretion of the treating physician- be placed into the stomach to aspirate the gastric residual. The protocol gives instructions to the nurses on how to handle residuals exceeding 200 ml. Of note that the protocol does not include the routine use of prokinetic agents or post-pyloric tubes and these options are left to the treating physicians to consider when the patient continues to demonstrate evidence of feeding intolerance. The type of feeding tube (large-bore nasogastric tube or small-bore nasogastric tube with or without guide wire) is left entirely to the treating physician. In addition, the protocol includes keeping the patient in a semi-recumbent position to reduce the risk of aspiration. The protocol also discourages discontinuation of enteral feeding during diagnostic tests, usual nursing care or routine bedside procedures because of its significant negative impact on feeding delivery and the lack of significant aspiration risk of briefly placing the patient in supine position.
The goal of caloric intake in patients in study group is 40-60% of the estimated need throughout the study period (permissive underfeeding group). These goals will be achieved by daily assessments of the caloric intake for the previous increasing the intake according to the nutrition sliding scale provided with the feeding protocol. Calculation of caloric intake will take into account IV infusions of dextrose and propofol. Protein requirement will be calculated as 0.8-1.0g/kg based on the patient condition and underlying diseases in the first 5 days in both groups17. For patients who are randomized to the Replenish Protocol group, Beneprotein formula will be used to supplement protein to receive 2 g/kg/day protein requirement. Patients in the control group will continue to receive 0.8-1 g/kg/day. All patients included in the study in both arms will receive multivitamins (containing vitamin E, vitamin C and trace elements like Selenium, Zinc and Copper) daily.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged ≥ 18 years
- Mechanically ventilated
- Receiving enteral feeding via nasogastric/orogastric or duodenal or PEG or jejunostomy tubes and
- Expected to stay ≥ 1 week in the ICU
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lack of commitment to ongoing life support, which
- Underlying pre-existing condition with expected 6 month mortality > 50%.
- Enteral feeding cannot be started within 48 hours of admission.
- Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
- Oral feeding.
- Chronic renal failure
- Patients with chronic liver disease
- Renal replacement therapy
- Pregnancy.
- Kidney transplant
- Post-liver transplant.
- Post cardiac arrest.
- Burn patients.
- Prisoners
